title: Walks around Cottenham Walking Route

images.title: Green, Cottenham by Bikeboy, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Green, Cottenham

images.title: Cottenham Lode by Rose and Trev Clough, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cottenham Lode. A channel which takes water from several small streams rising north-west of Cambridge, and flows into the Great Ouse near Wilburton.

images.title: Almshouses, Cottenham by Bikeboy, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Almshouses, Cottenham

images.title: Cottenham: All Saints by John Sutton, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cottenham, All Saints. The earliest documented evidence of a church in Cottenham is in a Charter of Saxon King Eadred in 948. This church was replaced by a Norman edifice in the 12th century, fragments of which can still be seen in the present building, which itself dates from the 15th century.

images.title: Cottenham: Old Thatch and other old thatched houses by John Sutton, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cottenham, Old Thatch and other old thatched houses

images.title: Rodney Burton / Rampton Bridge, Cambs
images.caption: Rampton Bridge, Cambs. spanning the Westwick Brook, taken from the footpath forming the parish boundary between Rampton and Cottenham.

images.title: Keith Edkins / Rampton Village Sign
images.caption: Rampton Village Sign. Featuring All Saints' Church and other local views, it doubles as the local War Memorial

images.title: Keith Edkins / Giant's Hill
images.caption: Giant's Hill. Giant's Hill was constructed as a castle mound by King Stephen's forces to counter the fenland rebellion of Geoffrey de Mandeville, but left unfinished when de Mandeville died in 1144. The site is managed by Cambridgeshire County Council Farms Estate.

description: This Cambridgeshire based village lies just a few miles north of the famous university city of Cambridge. It includes a pretty village green, picturesque old almshouses, quaint thatched cottages and a church dating back to the 15th century. This circular walk takes you to the neighbouring village of Rampton. It includes a waterside section along Cottenham Lode which runs just to the north of the settlement. Rampton is also very pretty with the historic Giant's Hill castle mound and another nice village green. To continue your walking around Cottenham head west to visit one of the local highlights at Fen Drayton Lakes. There's some lovely waterside footpaths and lots of wildlife to look out for at the popular nature reserve.
display_address: Well Pharmacy, 222, High Street, Cottenham, South Cambridgeshire, Cambridgeshire, Cambridgeshire and Peterborough, England, CB24 8RZ, United Kingdom
